um there's a bunch of stuff there the most important things for this talk is that I was a co-founder and CTO of a business I'm going to be talking about
the product that we built in that business today and I'm now a domain driven design trainer and consultant because I used domain driven design that
is actually what DDD stands for um on this project and I loved it so much I decided I wanted to
professionally help teams make use of it uh I've been talking uh sorry the thing
that all of these things have in common uh that I do is I'm really passionate and empowering technology teams to drive
business success so it's operating at that intersection of Business and Technology I've been talking to a number of people
here over the last few days and uh there's mixed understanding of what domain-driven design is some people were
like driven but and some people were like yeah we throw Eric Evans book at new candidates and we don't let them
touch a line of code until they've written a five-page essay on how amazing it is which good on you
um been Eric's own words so Eric Evans the guy who invented it in 2003 he wrote this book domain driven design tackling
complexity in the heart of software he talks about as a framework and a technical vocabulary for driving out
your software designs based on the domain that you're working in the sphere of knowledge that your customers inhabit
and he hopes that it would help teams approach this process systematically while this is a very precise definition
as is Eric's want I do find some people find it a little bit too abstract so I
prefer to explain it with a meme inside you there are two wolves one has a focus on technology the other has a focus on
the domain we got into this trade because we love technology we like building software and systems so our
technology wolf is very strong very loud how's it the moon and we howl back we
love it we can explain the difference between RDS and dynamodb and whether you should use reactor View and all these kind of technical concerns
but for many of us the wolf that focuses on the domain is a little bit malnourished a little bit sort of
whimpering in the corner and so what I wanted to do with this talk is to share with you a domain modeling Journey I'm
not going to talk about how we implemented this system I'm going to talk to you about how we came to understand the domain that we were
working in the concepts that our stakeholders had in their heads their mental models how we learned about it
how it evolved over time and how we a little bit translated it into working software but mostly about the domain
Concepts the business was operating in the space of healthcare and in particularly
payments and insurance so typical interaction which most of us are probably familiar with is a doctor might
send a quote to the Australian government saying how much would you pay me so to provide a service to a person they'll come back with an estimate
they'll do the work and claim that they did the work and then they'll get paid and sometimes the person themselves is
involved they might pay some extra money and get reimbursed but either way there's a transfer of funds in exchange
for services provided and that transfer of funds is not necessarily Just Between the person receiving the services and
the person we're providing them there's a some other entity in the middle so this kind of interaction is very
common and if you look at the broader landscape it's quite complex we've got hospitals also claiming from the government we've got private insurers
we've got physiotherapists we've got dentists we've got hospitals also claiming from private insurers we've got state-based schemes for workers
compensation and Road Accident Recovery also having hospitals also having GPS also having physiotherapists we've got
Farm roll out of vaccination programs which may be engaged with pharmacists but the pharmacists are also claiming
from the recovery programs who are also recruiting from the federal government and to top it all off we've got on the
side of the world of disability funding which we are going to dive into a little bit today because people with a
disability receive services from physiotherapists and other medical professionals but they also receive services from specialized Disability
Services providers and sometimes non-health or disability care providers at all transport and another kind of you
know Home Improvement and other accommodations that need to be built so let's dig into the world of disability
funding because it's an interesting story in the olden days I'll call it the bad old days the way it worked as the
government would find a specialized provider and say Here's fifty thousand dollars look after this person for the next year and then they give them the
money and that was kind of it just their hands we're done the person with a disability was up on
the side very little visibility over their budgets or what was remaining or what it was being spent on certainly no choice in control or autonomy over the
service providers that they were working with now I just want to take a moment and say because we're talking about disability
I've used the iconography of a wheelchair here it's really important to note that every person with a disability
has a unique lived experience no two disabilities are the same no two people's experiences are the same and I
only use this iconography because it's a common and standard pictorial representation to illustrate what we're talking about but it's certainly in no
way intend to imply that every person with a disability has the experience of a wheelchair user and with that in mind I'm going to give
you a little bit of disability Theory in the very bad old days they have what was known as the medical model of disability a doctor would examine
someone and say yes there is something wrong with you you have a disability we need to fix you there's something wrong
with you as a person I think now most of you are probably having a reaction that feels a little bit disquarded by that
then there evolved a charity model of disability where a group of well-meaning people would say well you clearly need
some help let's raise some money for you we'll run a fundraising Drive get some donations we'll help pay for any sort of
services or adaptations or accommodations that you need it was well-meaning but it still left people
disempowered they were dependent on this uncontrollable source of funds and still didn't really have a lot of control over
their lives thankfully eventually there evolved a thing called the social model of disability and and this is really
fascinating this sort of says that the experience of disability is actually a property of the
relationship between a person and the society that they live in it is not an intrinsic property of an individual
to explain what that means more concretely for those of us in the room who are fully sighted imagine that you
were transferred it's transported to a world where everybody else can see in the dark do you think in this world they would
build lighting they would build Street lamps they would provide Illumination in any kind of environment of course they
would not most of society would not need it you exactly as you are with no change to your biology or your brain would be
considered disabled in this world when you conduct that thought experiment it really highlights that when we talk
about disability we're not talking about a property of a person we're talking about the experience of living in a world that was not built for you
I don't want to dismiss the fact that many people living with disability have disabilities that Encompass extreme pain
or discomfort and obviously an environmental change is not going to alleviate that but it certainly goes a long way to understanding what it's like
you know for a person with a disability to live in a society that that has disregarded their needs
we can go further than the social model and talk about the human rights model of disability which says not only is the
social model correct but every person has an intrinsic human right to fight for Equitable access to services in
society to live a fulfilled and Rich life and I think when it's explained in this way you'd be hard-pressed to find anyone
who would disagree with that point so in Australia following this model they come up with a thing called the national
disability insurance scheme which I'm sure a lot of people have heard about I'm not going to talk about the politics of it obviously it was plagued by
politics and various execution issues but you can see here the principles and the intentions behind it were
you know admirable I think to explain how things worked once they rolled this
out a person with a disability could go to any service provider request a quote they would get that quote they could
choose to engage that service provider or not go to somebody else if they did choose to engage them they could then
ask the government to pay which they would do or sometimes they would get the money back themselves and then Supply
that money to the service provider so this really empowered the people with the disability and their communities of
care that's the other part of the iconography there um to you know be at the center of the decisions made about the supports
adaptations and accommodations that they need to pursue their goals in life and to have Equitable access to the kind of
life that most Australians take for granted so if we go back to this landscape the reason that this is all important the
reason we're going to talk about this is because we saw a couple of opportunities to help here one was to simplify all of
these interactions every single line here was a different website a different form some of them were paper-based forms
that would take three months to get paid um but on top of that there was this opportunity here to help support the
success of this new disability funding scheme so we set ourselves this mission to support the success of the funding
model by facilitating transparency efficiency and ease of access to claiming and payments we're not medical
professionals we're not specialists in support care we couldn't help you down that way but we're technologists we could build a technology platform that
would make it easier to operate more efficient to operate and home and hopefully enhance the probability of
success now we had a problem here commonly known in the marketplaces the chicken and egg
problem there was no one group of people involved in this program that we could offer a value to until we had other
parties engaged with the program but thankfully this model which was putting people with a disability at the
center of their decisions actually sort of broke that problem for us at the start of the interaction they would have
conversations with the scheme and say let's agree on a plan your goals and what budgets are appropriate to help you meet those goals
um and so if we look at this kind of financial flow model that we had if we focus in down on the interaction between
the provider and the person with a disability we could actually offer some support there there are a lot of existing relationships between service
providers and participants in the scheme as they're known and so we set ourselves
an initial goal to support participants in managing the use of their plans so with all of that context and
background we can start to talk about the software design how are we modeling our systems to reflect what was really
going on in the real world and most importantly how were the people involved thinking about it what were their mental models
so we turn to domain-driven design and in the book there's this diagram which talks about responsibility layers and we
use this concept of responsibility layers to help us come up with a high-level organizing principle for the components that our software was going
to use there's an example of that also from the book where you can see that the layers at the top have dependency on the layers
below but the layers below do not their ignorance of the layers above you can think about this in the technocratic
domain as being similar to the presentation layer being ignorant of the persistence layer but here we're not talking about technical concerns we're
talking about domain Concepts real ideas and mental models for things and processes that happen in the domain
so we came up from analysis from a lot of conversations and discussions and collaborative modeling with stakeholders
and potential customers with three key responsibility layers um an administrative layer an operations
layer handling the actual requests for payment and the approvals thereof and forecasting remaining balances and so on
and then a finance layer reflecting the actual movement of the money we went down approach of using things
for the domain driven design calls bounded contexts we identified a set of contacts within which we could draw a
boundary and say within this boundary there's a set of Concepts that are cohesive amongst each other and are
hopefully Loosely coupled from Concepts that we're going to put into other contexts so we'd say that the administrative layer would handle things
like onboarding events would flow up into the claiming layer so it was aware of the kinds of claims that might come
in events would flow across to a plane tracking context which would handle things like forecasting budgets
being aware of how much funds are remaining in a given participant's plan and then activity would flow out to a
settlement context to then facilitate payments a Reconciliation context to keep track of and make sure that there
was no money going astray and of course the billing context we need to get paid we need to invoice the various parties are going to pay for our services
so this was their initial Vision initial model that we had um thankfully being a startup we didn't have to build the
whole thing all at once we could start with just these two we by understanding the domain and seeing where was the
value we focused in on building the things that were valuable first and leaving the rest of it to be done manually in the first days so we focused
in on the claiming process and the plan tracking code context because that would allow us to add value to our participants lives so let's dig into how
that those interactions worked we had a service provider who would submit a claim a request for payment and to the claiming context via an API that would
run through some rules including a check with the participant and their community of care whether the work had actually been done if they confirmed that it had
been it would flow through to the plane tracking context and we had an app where they could visualize what was happening
in their budgets and you know how much they had spent we launched this out to the market got some really great feedback one of which was that graph
which is going up showing how much has been spent should really be going down show me how much money I have left what
can I spend now kind of obvious when you think about it if we had not put this out there we wouldn't have thought about it we're not we're not the users the
users are the users and they can tell us what's useful and valuable to them and that was helpful in informing the internal models domain models that were
within that plan tracking context and because of this separation we were able to just update the plan tracking context and not have to update the claiming
context so that was quite helpful and this separation felt like it was a good a good design decision
then we got a new uh use case came along that we hadn't thought about there were other service providers that we hadn't
engaged with who were still sending invoices to this participant maybe a PDF or a piece of paper and they needed to
represent that in their plans and we'll say well how are we going to get that into this forecast um we could have submitted it into the
claiming context but the claiming context was not designed for that it was designed for receiving claims from someone who hasn't uh you know is not
necessarily authorized we've received that money whereas this is something that is implicitly authorized and maybe
it doesn't have as much data as we need because it's coming in on a paper invoice and so this is something that domain driven design tells you to look
out for don't try and stuff two things into the same model just because they look kind of similar so we recognized from this that it was
actually a separate context and we built out a new service a new context called pay invoice where the flow would go
through in this kind of fashion and eventually end up in the plan tracking context this helped us to realize as we started
to evolve the solution that we actually had inadvertently resulted in a claiming context that was not very cohesive Adam
was talking about cohesion before in relation to business Concepts and by using domain driven design and focusing on these domain Concepts that helped us
be alert to the reality that we had inadvertently end up with a low cohesion module here because really it was doing
two things it was processing claims coming in from this API sometimes bulk claims in a file and it was also
checking all the rules of the scheme to make sure that this was valid and legitimate to be paid and to be forming part of the expenditure on this person's
plan so we reorganize things this is exactly the same structure I've just moved the
positions of them but the lines are the same to sort of highlight the difference we disconnected all of these contexts
and split out the rules part into a separate context we call the claims engine and rewired up these contexts to
flow directly into it and you see though so checking the rules happened in one so we split them out so we had this
commitment and this is something domain driven design encourages you should encourage you to do when you learn something new about the domain when you
realize that your models in your system are not in alignment with the domain and the way that the stakeholders think
about the world you should try and reflect that new understanding in your code as quickly as possible otherwise
you end up in the kind of situation that Adam was talking about earlier and this concept of splitting it out in
this way seemed to prove very useful because then there was another use case that sort of slotted neatly into the
pattern which was that sometimes service providers who didn't have an API integration you know I still wanted to submit
invoices and so we built them an app and in that app they were submitting claims but those claims looked kind of
different they needed to be in a draft status they needed to be constructed by querying lists of potential item codes
so they couldn't be handled by the other context and we built a dedicated context for that purpose Michael mentioned the
other day that in when you do domain driven design you often find lots of different definitions of the same ID and
that was the case here we would have a claim represented in multiple contexts they would share an ID but their
representation in each context was very different and suited to the needs of that particular part of the business process and in a lot of ways this worked
really well now I want to dive into that claims engine because everything I've talked about so far is what domain driven
design calls strategic architecture it's the high level big picture building blocks and their organizing principles but within that context we had to come
up with an actual domain model and we could Implement that in working software so while these boxes represent domain
Concepts the reality in the implementation was that they were became classes in the code
um so we had a claim that was kind of the center of the the story and then we had a bunch of domain services that were
encapsulations of business processes without state so the things with stars are like entities they they manage data
and process and behavior um but the things with the blue boxes were just managing Behavior without data and they
it's useful when you're trying to correlate between multiple entities so in our case to approve a claim we had
all these rules that we had to process so the claim approver would construct a rules chain and then build up the rules
chain of the rules that needed to be executed for that claim and then evaluate them all and provide feedback if any of the rules um didn't pass and
those rules usually involve comparing some data on the claim like what item is it for against some related data like
what's the associated data with that item code what's the valid price for it and so on and there are a whole bunch of these rules and a really important one
was sufficient funds rule is there enough balance on their account and so this was a model that we came up with by
exploring the domain with our experts and trying to tease apart what are all the rules that they think need to be evaluated and we came up with a model
that neatly encapsulated either each of those rules and the reference data that they would relate to the sufficient
funds are always quite interesting um because we had all these budgets or accounts of balances that needed to be
checked um and so for this one it's felt a lot like a finance domain and we didn't want
to you know reinvent the wheel so we kind of looked to things like double entry booking bookkeeping and accounting
specifically give us inspiration for how we should model out that part of the domain so if we dive into that part it turned
out that it was quite helpful but there were some challenges and I'm going to share that now so we had an account with
a balance um multiple accounts involved one of them was about how much did we owe a
given service provider one was what's available on this support category which is a budget allocated to a specific specific goal and one was you know how
much money notionally is coming from the funding program and then when a claim was approved we would Journal a transfer of funds from
one account to another and then the balance would change and then when we actually paid the money out or when
supposedly the money had been paid out there would be another transfer in the money owing to this provider would Dev
it back down to zero in the balance now this is where we can talk a little bit about some technocratic concerns and how domain
modeling can help you unravel those technocratic concerns because one of the issues here is about transactional
consistency we had to make a decision about which access was more important to care about in terms of a database
transaction is it the account balance does it need to be consistent with the list of journal entries against that
account or was it the journal that the debits and the credits had to always add up to zero dollars if they didn't then
there was potentially a mismatch in the funding and you might say well why not just update it all in one database
transaction that's kind of the default option right domain driven design has kind of guided people to say that's not
a great idea it's not it doesn't build scalable systems and when you really look at the Domain model you can sort of find out that you don't necessarily
always need to do that um it's worth considering that a ironically in this scenario the
canonical example of why a database transaction is useful is for the transfer of funds between one account to another you want to make sure that you
don't lose money as it goes but the reality is this is actually a terrible use case for a database transaction
particularly in a highly concurrent highly scalable system because what happens when you have two transactions in parallel the first
transaction kicks off checks the balance does all the things it needs to do and then commits but if another one has come
in at the same time a concurrent transaction which also has contention another word which represents the fact
that these two transactions interacting with the same instances the same entities what are you going to do at the
end you've checked the balance before it was committed and then do you overwrite it there's a
few options that you can do here the default that very naive Solutions embody is to do nothing and that leave the
balance is incorrect because only the results of the second transaction end up overwriting the results of the first
transaction the other which a lot of Frameworks give us support for is to impose some sort of concurrency detection sometimes it's optimistic or
pessimistic and we've got time to dive into the details of that but the problem is if that second transaction fails it's a terrible user experience There's No
Business reason for it to fail you know it should have succeeded the the funds were potentially there so it's a
terrible user experience a lot of Frameworks when they say hey I failed because of a concurrency error they say
you should retry this transaction so you can detect it and automatically retry it you know it's better not necessarily a
great user experience could be delays depending on what you how long you wait before you retry and how often do you retry and it's in highly concurrent
systems you can end up retrying multiple times and still having it fail every time so domain driven design actually gives
us a solution to this problem which is to say try not to let these transactions span over so many operations really
consider in the domain what's important to be consistent and what's not and in a standard accounting system you can model
it in this way this is from an event storming model which is really common in domain driven design the orange stickies
represent events and the yellow stickies represent Aggregates or transactionally consistent boundaries of state so when
the claim is approved we could create the journal commit that transaction and publish an event asynchronously to say
that the entry has been journaled and then update the two accounts independently and in parallel in isolated separated transactions and then
they would they would advertise via an event that their balance had been changed and in most accounting system this works fine because the account
balance doesn't actually need to be transactionally consistent nobody looks at the account balance until the end of day they're doing a report at end of day
or end of month and it's very unlikely that in the microsecond of the original Journal that anyone cares whether the
balance is consistent but in our case we couldn't do this we did actually have to
worry about when we checked the balance because if we approved the claim thinking they had enough funds and it turned out they didn't if we had
followed this model we would have ended up with negative balances which when it's government money is a terrible terrible outcome
so we came up with this approach it's it's complicated and when I watched Sarah's talk yesterday I was reminded of
coming up with this design because it was probably more complex than it needs to be but it did have some advantages
which is that we could pre-authorize the claim against the account check that the funds were there and then immediately
give the user some feedback
come back oh there we go
um immediately give the user some feedback and all the rest of the flow of events and transaction committals could
happen asynchronously in the background without bothering the user and so if there was a concurrency issue in those
later portions of the transaction they could retry as many times as you wanted and it didn't really matter because because
um the user wasn't going to be affected and this is a really common pattern when you do domain driven design because by analyzing the domain and understanding
What's significant and important to the user and how they think about um you know the critical factors of
things that actually have to happen together at the same time you can actually design more scalable and Main and robust systems because you can
shrink those transaction durations and and allow this transactions to interleave with each other rather than holding locks on databases for long
periods of time so that's the extent of the technocratic kind of conversation the rest of it is back to just talking
about domain modeling except for just briefly to say what I'd wish we'd done is to actually identify the true points
of contention in the system which again comes from understanding the domain deeply turns out that transactions on
the participants account had low contention because one participant is not receiving many services at the same
time the transactions on the provider's account were high contention because they might have had many many workers
who are providing Services concurrently so we could have kept the low conduction account into the same transaction the
journaling and kept the high contention account out of it in an eventually consistent asynchronous Manner and if
you don't stop and think about the domain and the domain models and what's important to your users you would never have been you know realize that this
kind of transactional boundary would have actually led to a far more scalable reliable and happy user experience as
you scale up so that got us through phase one then we needed to validate these concepts by starting to interact with another
funding program because although we had sort of solved the chicken and egg Problem by servicing one side of the the
fence we wanted to expand the pool of service providers because we wanted to make sure there were more people who
were willing to engage and provide services to people with a disability and what they were telling us was that what they needed was to access more funding
programs because they didn't want to have all these different crisscrossing lines and five different processes to get paid so luckily we were able to find
another funding program a state-based road accident recovery program who was willing to engage with this because they
saw the service providers we already had and they saw value in starting to receive their claims digitally as
opposed to by paper they wanted an API to allow them to do a bunch of operations with us and so that was kind
of the next thing we were going to build and if we go back to our original this is called a context map our map of the context in our system we'd already built
everything in green and in order to support this new client we just had to build this orange part this orange part
because they wanted us to manage the payments finally make some updates to the claims engine and at first we thought this is great
our original Vision was quite accurate where it must be domain modeling so once we just got it right the first time
and then we dug into it deeper and we discovered that the terminology was all
over the place the first program totally referred to service providers and claims the second one had completely different definitions for the same words and then
a whole bunch of new words that referred to Concepts that didn't even exist in the original domain model and this slide
is actually the Genesis is the title of this talk when customers don't share a language because domain-driven design
advises us that the best thing to do is to create in collaboration with your stakeholders a ubiquitous language and
use that shared language everywhere in conversations and in code but how could we do that when we had two customers who
didn't even speak the same language but we're kind of doing the same thing so we sort of identified that we had two options we could
explicitly say these two customers need separate bounded context they've got separate languages that means they've
got separate models there's a common phrase in and domain driven design which is a change in the language is a change in the model
or we could try and come up with a unified language now this was a really hard decision to make on one side we saw
ourselves potentially having to create 15 30 different contexts to support the number of programs we envisage
supporting and that didn't seem like a scalable solution from a maintenance perspective but on the other hand we were aware of the risks of trying to use
language that was inconsistent with the way our customers talked in the end we decided to go with option two because we thought that as a heuristic if we can at
least be consistent within our company that's a very important goal to have and the reality was we were never going to
be consistent with all of the clients so we came up with this list I'm not going to go through everything in detail
but we came up with this term and actually we refactored the code to use this terminology everything we had
written so far so I shouldn't have used the word refactor Dave's going to pull me off with a shepherd's crook he doesn't like it but we modified the code
we updated it to use this language and even within the weeks of us doing that
we saw that changes were flowing more smoothly and easily and there was less confusion compared to when we were
trying to implement that second programs model into the first programs um you know code that used that first
program's language another interesting thing is that this second program didn't actually need this
rule all that energy and effort we put into solving the transactional consistency problem for the funds check
um was irrelevant because they did not care they would allocate funding for a
person when they had a road accident and they did not have a limit on that they weren't going to prevent them from getting care that they needed they were
more interested in monitoring the spending and uh maybe saying hang on you're spending more than the average
person when they've had this kind of accident as a postdoc analysis now it's hard to work out how to design a domain
model to support these two different scenarios so we went with a really cheap option which was we had a Boolean flag on the account balance check required
true or false and if it was false we would let the balance go negative now I didn't feel good about this I'm
going to be honest it was uh it was not you know my naive idealism around what domain-driven design should be I should
have a really neat encapsulated domain model that reflects my customers mental models um but I am a big fan of all Cunningham
and he had this to say about this kind of approach I'm never in favor of writing code poorly but I am in favor of writing code to reflect your current
understanding of a problem is if that understanding is partial and ironically this was his original definition of
technical debt the gap between uh you know what you understood at the time you started and what you understood later particularly in relation to the domain
and it's kind of been Twisted semantic diffusion has come up a few talks this conference um to kind of mean anytime
you take a technical shortcut thankfully the great Martin Fowler has given us a more cohesive framework to kind of
understand these things now some of the changes I talked about earlier splitting that claiming context into claims engine
and claiming was this example here it was inadvertent but prudent we launched without knowing it we discovered later
that we were wrong we changed it immediately we discovered it this one now with the Boolean flag was more The
Prudent deliberate model we have to ship now and deal with the consequences committing to change it later once we understood better what the model should
actually be I'd like to say that we successfully only lived in The Prudent column
I don't think any of us can honestly say that we only live in The Prudent column uh of course we did have some reckless
technical debt particularly in our front end if we have a delightful nicely architected back end uh who thinks that
that was perfectly reflected in the modularization of the front end of course not it was a beautiful react big
ball of mud um and that was definitely more of this kind of inadvertent uh Reckless
technical debt because it's not that we didn't understand layering we actually had really nicely technocratically
isolated layers presentation CSS API access all that stuff but we hadn't kept the domain concept separated and this is
again reinforced for me the value of domain driven design not just in the back end but up and down the whole stack and using consistent language everywhere
in App application even in the front end so I want to talk briefly about coupling because this was an experience of
tightly coupled systems and I really love this quote from Constantine and Jordan in structured Design This is not a new idea this is 1979 he came up they
they wrote this and I've bolded the significant point that coupling you know can be operationalized as the
probability of any coding debugging or modifying one module you'll have to take into account something about another module so I bowled that coding debugging
and modifying because it highlights that actually the experience of coupling is relevant to a specific change that
you're making and this is actually very um you know coherent with Adam's talk about looking for the hot spots in your
code if we had a change to a color scheme in our front end that was actually very easy to do because we had isolated those technocratic concerns so
you you exchanged like that was quite straightforward if we had a change to the business rules of the claims engine
like a new rule for evaluating a claim because we had isolated the back end components into these bounded contexts
that was also very easy to do so that was nice and simple and when we had those kind of changes we felt good we built a Loosely coupled system the team
could easily handle that kind of change but when we had a change in the front end that was related to domain Concepts
or perhaps a couple of domain Concepts in a flow the process change was very very hard in the front end and similarly
there were some core models that we'd allowed to proliferate and be shared between between a context for example we had to change a field from a date time
to a date time offset in order to track the time zone and we had to change all of these contexts at the same time in
order to achieve the outcome there we didn't strictly have to deploy them all at the same time we could change them one by one and have sort of you know
loose coupling allowing us to you know have backwards and forwards compatibility and all that sort of stuff but it was still a lot more work than it
should have been so core data model changes that were shared you know was not a great experience so it sort of led
me to believe that coupling is not necessarily an intrinsic property of a system it's a property in relation to a
specific change that you're about to make and you can't create a design that is perfect for every possible future change that you might get you can't
predict all the changes that you might get but notwithstanding that we had a couple of these changes that were hard to do I do believe that domain driven
design and aligning your design and your models with a really clear picture of the way your customers think about the
world gives you the best bet of reducing the probability that you're going to have changes that are going done across
more components of your system and I want to come back to this quote because there's another part of it which I'm going to bolded separately a
programmer will have to take into account something in another module the person is a key part of this experience
so yes we've got a system but also we've got teams who are managing this system and that's teams have individuals within
them and you can kind of think about this interaction as being a system and a bunch of teams as a socio-technical
system and that social technical system has teams as an organizing component but it has individuals but also components
and the investment that you make in onboarding and training those individuals into understanding your
domain and your technical practices will actually have a big impact on the cost of change even if the system design is
not as Loosely coupled as you might like because someone that knows that you have to change two sides of a boundary can
just do it very quickly and it's not a high cost of change someone that doesn't know has to do it and then discover that actually things haven't worked so well
and then they have to work out what else they need to change so I'm not saying that education is a solution for report design like you should fix up your
design but you have to do all of it you have to consider all of it because it's not just in the technical solution it's in the socio-technical system that
encompasses everybody involved with the system so finally we made it to phase three because we did have to eventually evolve
our concept of how this was going to work step back a little bit the interaction had kind of ended up being a real
simplification you remember that original diagram with all the crisscrossing lines it had become this we had started to be the layer in the
middle a consistent coherent experience for service providers who would ask that question we would evaluate the rules if
it was fine we'd tell the program yep they did it we checked all your rules in there okay can can we send we're going to send them the money
um or can you send them the money and sometimes we would say sorry we can't pay because of you know whatever reason
and then we got another funding program and we had a very interesting experience was that uh we went live with them it
turns out they were also evaluating the rules and when they did it they sometimes got different answers and it wasn't because we had misimplemented the
logic it was because as you saw before the rules were a lot about checking the claim against reference data and the
reference data between our two systems was not always perfectly in sync and so sometimes they would think that the
person didn't have enough money or they did or that the service provider was valid or not and this was leading to a
lot of a lot of challenges and they said to us why are you even doing the rules we can do the rules um can you just give us the claim and
then we'll tell you whether you should approve it and pay it or not and they're like well I mean yeah we could do that
it's not what we're doing for everybody else so we went and spoke to the other people and they said actually we were better be better for us you know why
didn't you offer that in the first place well you didn't ask for it but you know this is the experience of learning as you go
um but thankfully they were willing to do it not necessarily all at the same time though so we had to embark on a bit
of a change we had to basically get rid of all of these rules but it wasn't going to be effective to just slice them
out of this context and we didn't want to go in and start billing off of if conditions about this time you do the rule and this time you don't
um so we employed a thing called the strategy sorry the um Strangler fig
pattern and we basically wanted to transform ourselves from a rules engine into a routing engine so what we did is
we moved our original rules engine up mentally our model became that was kind of up in the back of the system that was
V1 and then we built V2 a completely new system we're able to launch it very quickly it was fresh code it did exactly
what it needed to do it was a routing engine and so if a funding program was able to engage with us and to do the
rules themselves we could just send the claims up to them and they would tell us if it was okay if they couldn't we could send it up to our own rules engine and
then it could evaluate the rules on their behalf and send it back and then gradually the funding programs would connect in to our V2 and we were able to
get rid of it the other side of it was the service providers obviously we had a lot who were already connected into V1
new ones would go into V2 gradually we migrated the old ones onto V2 and then
gradually we might go to the funding programs onto V2 sorry and then we're able to complete the decommission V1 and
this was something we committed to doing as quickly as we could it did take some time it took about a year or two to complete um but we were operating a live
system in both sides the whole time kept backwards compatibility and we're delivering value to all our stakeholders
consistently so it was actually I think a really successful project to briefly dive into that V2 because I'm getting
close to end of time um there's just one so I guess I think lesson to be learned from that we did
model it out slightly differently we wanted to use asynchronous notifications to all the various parties so like a web
hook out to the funding program so here's a new claim to be approved when they would tell us that it was or rejected we would then use a web hook to
go back to the provider to say hey this is the outcome and this is an interesting case because that notification activity was not a domain
activity it was not something that embodied business rules it was a technocratic concern it was very flexible and generic we had
uh sort of data filtering so data driven filtering of subscriptions that would allow us to subscribe to send webhooks
or signalr notifications or cues based on detecting different events in the system that were matching against different filters and it was lovely but
the the thing that's really significant here is that we put a lot of effort into keeping the domain Concepts on one side
and the technocratic concepts on the other you might think about that notification Hub as a platform service a
domain agnostic technical capability that other domain Services were able to take advantage of
so to finally recap Lessons Learned there's obviously a lot of detail in

fearlessly rethink the large-scale structure throughout the Project Life Cycle the team should not saddle itself with a structure conceived of early on
when no one understood the domain or the requirements very well unfortunately that Evolution means that your final structure will not be available at the

base in a yaml file and if you have done that it's an extension to an IDE that will give you hover and autocomplete
with those domain terms to try and encourage you to use the domain terminology in your code base and to help you understand the terms as they're
understood in that context it's context aware so if you have the same word in different folders or in different repositories you'll get different
definitions so in this example it's from like a student University admissions domain and hovering over the registered
student request which is a dto you get both the definition of student and register it's language agnostic because
it's just looking for the text that matches the word it matches pluralization so it'll work in Java C
sharp typescript markdown files really anything there's no constraints because it's just looking for text that matches
the words and this is something that I really wanted to build to help Developers
connect with and make better use of the language of their domains and understand the domains that they're working in and why they're building them
I have a vision of taking this further and I have a POC of this which is a slack bot so if you're having a conversation with someone outside the
